awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of compressible fluids near a free surface and collisional kinetic models
awd_abstract_narration:
Jang
DMS-1212142

     The investigator studies nonlinear partial differential equations arising in gas and fluid dynamics and related applications.  The first topic regards the dynamics of compressible fluids near a moving boundary driven by gravity.  The models considered in this topic include Euler equations in Newtonian gravity theory and relativistic Euler equations in special relativity, and two-fluid Navier-Stokes equations with constant viscosity.  The focus is on the investigation of important physical phenomena such as gravitational collapse and Rayleigh-Taylor instability.  The second topic concerns the qualitative behavior of collisional kinetic models such as Boltzmann equations and Fokker-Planck equations.  The asymptotic behavior of Boltzmann equations in the presence of electromagnetic fields with focus on magnetohydrodynamic regimes is investigated when the mean free path is sufficiently small.  Also the dynamics driven by Fokker-Planck collisions are studied on a bounded domain. 

     Compressible fluids and gases are the common objects found everywhere in nature.  The study of moving boundary problems for compressible fluids and the asymptotic limit of kinetic gases is very important because of their rich applications in mathematical sciences and engineering as well as the fascinating mathematics behind them.  The investigation of the dynamics of fluids near a free surface and the dynamics of mesoscale collisions balanced with electromagnetic fields aims to advance knowledge in this fundamental area of mathematics.  The problems addressed in this project are also very interesting to physicists, other scientists, and engineers.  The results provide some foundational evidences to other disciplines such as astrophysics, plasma physics, aerodynamics, and computational physics, chemistry, and biology, and is expected to lead to scientific and technological advances.

por.por_cntn:
The problems investigated by the PI under the scope of the award are physically motivated and address important physical phenomena such as gas expansion and collapses and Rayleigh–Taylor instability. They offer mathematical challenges and answering the questions requires new ideas and methods, which could open a new line of research and make an impact on other related models.

Compressible Euler-Poisson system is a fundamental hydrodynamic model describing the motion of self-gravitating stars. Non-moving isolated gas spheres, known as the Lane-Emden stars, are given by the static solutions of the Euler-Poisson system. The stability question of the Lane-Emden stars has been of a great interest among astrophysics and mathematics communities. The PI has shown a nonlinear instability result against radial perturbations in a super-critical regime conjectured by astrophysicists in a moving boundary framework. The Lane-Emden star is nonlinearly unstable in the critical regime. In this case, both expanding and collapsing homologous solutions exist. By facilitating the scaling symmetry of the system, the PI with collaborator has shown that the expanding profiles are nonlinearly stable for all future time, which also gives rise to the first global solutions to the Euler-Poisson system beyond special solutions. A further investigation on the dynamics of expanding gases modeled by compressible Euler equations was pursued. The PI and collaborator have shown the stability of affine motions without symmetry assumption in a vacuum free boundary framework, which verifies rigorously the stable gas expansion phenomenon into vacuum. 

The Rayleigh–Taylor instability occurs due to gravity when a heavy fluid tops a lighter fluid along the interface. A lot of progress on the incompressible fluids has been made in recent years, but only a few mathematical results are  available for compressible fluids. Together with collaborators, the PI investigated the dynamics of compressible viscous two fluids in a moving boundary framework. We have characterized the sharp criterion for stability and Rayleigh-Taylor instability near the equilibrium involving the surface tension value and the jump in the equilibrium density along the interface. 

The kinetic Fokker-Planck equation arises from various areas of science from plasma physics, biological science to finance. Physically applicable problems are often accompanied by boundary conditions. Despite the importance, the mathematical understanding of kinetic boundary value problems is still at an early stage. Together with collaborators, the PI has investigated the one-dimensional and multi-dimensional Fokker-Planck equation with absorbing boundary condition, which means there is no incoming particles on the boundary. In particular, we were able to study the detailed behavior of solutions near the singular set, and in multi-dimensional setting, we have shown that the convexity of the boundary is not needed to obtain the solution. 

Results of this award have been disseminated through journal publications and various seminar and conference talks. Also the award has provided an opportunity to mentor students.
